clinical_study.brief_title: Role of Oxytocin in Telling and Detecting Lies
clinical_study.official_title: Role of Oxytocin in Telling and Detecting Lies

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators are interested in the impact of intranasal oxytocin in unethical behavior.

detailed_description.textblock: The objective of this project is to further explore the role of oxytocin in moral judgment and ethical behavior. Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced in a variety of hypothalamic neurons. It is released into the brain or brought into general circulation through sensory stimuli in a pulsatile fashion. In social psychology research, oxytocin is hypothesized to coordinate both the causes and effects of positive social interactions in a biofeedback loop.

primary_outcome.description: To measure unethical behavior, we will calculate whether participants took more money than they actually earned on a problem-solving task.

arm_group.description: Intranasal placebo. 125 mg of 0.5% cholorobutanol to 50 ml saline, with approximately 5 pH. The solution will then be sterilized using a 0.22 micron filter.

intervention.description: Intranasal oxytocin is hypothesized to amplify the influence of social norms on unethical behavior.
